body.value:
Four more celebrities will take up the baking baton in The Great Sport Relief Bake Off.

Going head to head in the famous tent are ex-Spice Girl Geri Horner, BBC World Affairs Editor John Simpson, footballer and pundit Jermaine Jenas and singer and presenter Louise Redknapp.

The episode is hosted by comedian Ed Byrne and judges Mary Berry and Paul Hollywood are back on hand to put the bakers through their paces.

The first hurdle for the celebrities is the Signature challenge, where they take on savoury tarts. But will they be able to fulfil the judges’ requirements?

Up next it’s the Technical challenge: Mary’s chocolate and beetroot tray bake. The bakers must follow a stripped-back recipe to produce the moist, malty sponge, covered with a cream-cheese icing and decorated with candied beetroot. Who will struggle with the tricky task and who will impress the judges?

For the final, Showstopper bake the celebrities are asked to make 3D models of their favourite sporting moments out of biscuits. When it comes to the crunch, who will crumble under the pressure and who will triumph to take home the title of Star Baker?

While the celebrity bakers hope to inspire others to get involved in fundraising for Sport Relief, Clare Balding visits Kenya to learn more about the fight against malaria. Viewers will see Clare visit children in a hospital to see how money raise by Sport Relief is helping to make a difference.

You can watch The Great Sport Relief Bake Off on BBC One at 8pm.

Don’t forget you can also Get Baking for Sport Relief. To order your kit, which will include special recipes, visit sportrelief.com/bake-off-kit.

attributes.title: Things heat up in The Great Sport Relief Bake Off tent

body.value:
Greg James struggled on the penultimate day of Gregathlon - but with his fourth triathlon completed in Sheffield, the end is in sight.

The presenter faced a tough day, after taking a tumble from his bike when his legs seized up during the cycle. “My mind’s telling me yes, but my body, my body’s telling me no,” he joked.

Travel issues from Glasgow to Sheffield the previous day meant Greg only had a few hours’ of sleep before setting off on his cycle. “We had the worst journey last night from Glasgow to Sheffield, he said. “What was supposed to be a four hour journey turned into seven, so I've only had four hours sleep.

“The challenge has been harder than I thought, it's been exhausting travelling from city to city. It's been great having some guests come up and see me though, it'll be so nice having Grimmy and Example with me today. Even though my body is saying ‘please stop’, there is no way I'm giving in. I'm in the zone, even if my legs are not. I think they might still be in Belfast. I'm hanging on by a thread. I really need everyone's help and support to get through the next two days.”

With his leg muscles seizing up from fatigue and the biting cold, and his feet strapped into his pedals, Greg struggled to keep his balance on the bike and took a fall at the side of the road. Fortunately, he was unharmed and was on his way again in seconds.

His cycle was followed by an indoor swim, when he was joined by singer Example. He then ran through Sheffield city centre to the radio studio where he presented his afternoon show. Luckily he had fellow Radio 1 DJ and presenter Nick Grimshaw to cheer him along.

BBC Radio 1’s Gregathlon for Sport Relief will see Greg attempt to run, swim and cycle a triathlon a day for five consecutive days, across five UK cities. Tomorrow Greg will attempt to complete his final triathlon in Norwich.

Money raised from the challenge will be spent helping people living unimaginably tough lives, with half of the money raised used to make a difference right here in the UK. The other half is used to transform lives across the world’s poorest communities.

Greg needs your support to keep him going as he takes on his Gregathlon. You can sponsor him here.

Inspired by Greg? Why not take on your own challenge by signing up to the Sainsbury’s Sport Relief Games which take place from Friday 18th to Sunday 20th March. There are thousands of events across the UK with flagship Games in Belfast, Cardiff, Glasgow, Sheffield, Norwich and London.

Find your nearest event at sportrelief.com and sign up now!

Sir Steve Redgrave and Andrew ‘Freddie’ Flintoff MBE are set to go head to head in a Clash of the Titans for Sport Relief.

Five-time Olympic champion rower Sir Steve and cricket legend and broadcaster Freddie will each captain a team of celebrities as they go head to head in a number of Olympic sporting challenges as part of the Sport Relief Night of TV on Friday 18th March.

Sir Steve says “Winning gold medals at the Olympic Games was one thing, leading my team to victory in Clash of the Titans is another matter altogether,” he said. “Freddie Flintoff, bring it on.”

England all-rounder Freddie played a major role in the 2005 home Ashes victory over Australia and is no stranger to captaincy having led the England team during his international career. Freddie also captains a team on the sports-based comedy panel show A League Of Their Own.

“I took part in Clash of the Titans last time but we were robbed under John Bishop’s leadership,” he said. “This time I’m back and I’m not leaving without that trophy.”

The teams will be made up of famous faces from the worlds of entertainment and sport. With the Clash of the Titans trophy up for grabs, the celebrities will be put through their paces as they compete in a number of Olympic sporting challenges: Track Cycling, Rhythmic Gymnastics, Synchronised Swimming and, for the first time, Wrestling, plus a Triathlon race.

Clash of the Titans became a Sport Relief fixture in 2014 when Lord Sebastian Coe and his team of celebrities narrowly beat a team led by comedian John Bishop.

On the night, sports TV presenters Ore Oduba and Dan Walker will host all the action live from the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in London.

It promises to be a night filled with tension, entertainment and sporting rivalry and the public has the opportunity to buy tickets to watch all the action from the two venues; the Velodrome at Lee Valley VeloPark and the London Aquatics Centre.

Money raised this Sport Relief will be used to make a difference to people living incredibly tough lives, here at home in the UK and across the world’s poorest communities.

To buy tickets for Clash of the Titans go to www.seetickets.com/tour/sport-relief-2016/. Tickets cost £16, plus booking fees and £2.50 from the sale of each ticket will go directly to Sport Relief.

The Sport Relief Weekend takes place from Friday 18th to Sunday 20th March and sees the return of the Sainsbury’s Sport Relief Games. If you want to walk, run, swim or cycle yourself proud visit sportrelief.com.

attributes.title: Redgrave vs Flintoff in Clash of the Titans

attributes.title: Look what you’ve helped to achieve since 2007

body.value:
Greg James has set off on the first of his five triathlons for BBC Radio 1’s Gregathlon for Sport Relief.

The presenter began his epic challenge in Belfast, where he kicked off the first of his five triathlons, which will see him attempt to run, swim and cycle for five consecutive days, across five UK cities.

Setting off on his challenge, Greg braved the chilly open waters of Belfast Harbour Marina, before attempting to cycle around the city. He will complete his triathlon with a run past Belfast’s iconic sites, which include the old historic shipyard where the Titanic was built and launched, Stormont Castle and Belfast City Hall.

Greg will be attempting to complete over 50 miles and with rain forecast, he faces a soggy start to his challenge.

“I feel like jelly,” he said, before beginning his swim. “I feel really sick but I'm so excited. To quote The Weeknd: ‘I can't feel my face’ - it's so cold.

“This challenge is going to be difficult, but I've trained really hard for this and I can't wait to get going. Seeing everyone's posts on social tags has been really encouraging, so thank you. I'm going to do the best I can, make it entertaining along the way and hopefully raise lots of cash for Sport Relief.”

He also received a good luck message from Coldplay’s Chris Martin and The Saturdays’ Mollie King will be cheering him on towards the end of the day as he aims to cross the finish line to make it to his Radio 1 show at 4pm.

Money raised from the Gregathlon will be spent helping people living unimaginably tough lives, with half of the money raised used to make a difference right here in the UK. The other half is used to transform lives across the world’s poorest communities.

In January Greg travelled to Jordan to meet displaced families living in desperate conditions. He visited a nursery within the Azraq refugee camp and saw how Comic Relief funding is helping to give young children back their childhoods. The money raised through Sport Relief could help more children like these get a vital education, and support their families to maintain a crucial sense of community.

Greg needs your support to keep him going as he takes on his Gregathlon. You can sponsor him here: sportrelief.com/SponsorGreg.

Inspired by Greg? Why not take on your own challenge by signing up to the Sainsbury’s Sport Relief Games which take place from Friday 18th to Sunday 20th March. There are thousands of events across the UK with flagship Games in Belfast, Cardiff, Glasgow, Sheffield, Norwich and London.

Find your nearest event at sportrelief.com and sign up now!

attributes.title: Greg James begins his Gregathlon for Sport Relief

body.value:
Greg James has received support from some of the stars of British Triathlon ahead of his epic challenge for Sport Relief.

On Monday 8th February the presenter will begin his BBC Radio 1 Gregathlon for Sport Relief, which will see him attempt to complete a triathlon a day for five consecutive days, around five different UK cities.

Greg’s challenge will start off in Belfast, with BBC Radio 1 listeners and Sport Relief supporters able to track his efforts as he calls in live radio updates between his mammoth run, swim and cycle events. He will also be broadcasting his show between 4pm and 7pm every day.

Over the course of five days he will criss-cross his way around the nation via Cardiff, Glasgow and Sheffield before storming across the finish line in Norwich on Friday 12th February. Each of the five locations, will be the flagship cities of the Sainsbury’s Sport Relief Games and Greg will be encouraging the public at home to sign up to the event, which takes place from Friday 18th to Sunday 20th March.

Adding its support to Greg is the British Triathlon Federation, the national governing body of triathlon, which includes Triathlon England, TriathlonScotland and Welsh Triathlon.

“British Triathlon would like to wish Greg James good luck in his triathlon challenge,” chief executive Jack Buckner, says. “Completing five triathlons in five cities, in five days, is really a huge challenge, not just because of the distances and logistics involved, but also the winter weather. We hope that his swimming, cycling and running exploits help raise a lot of money for Sport Relief.”

Triathlete Vicky Holland, a 2014 Commonwealth Games gold and bronze medal winner, who is training for the Rio 2016 Olympics, also sent a message of support. “What a challenge,” she said. “Good luck for the Gregathlon and raising lots of money for Sport Relief. Keep warm, stay safe, make sure you’ve got a good masseuse and keep smiling!”

Taking in the sights with Greg along the way will be fellow presenters of BBC Radio 1, including Nick Grimshaw, and BBC 1Xtra.

Money raised from The Gregathlon will be spent helping people living unimaginably tough lives, with half of the money raised used to make a difference right here in the UK. The other half is used to transform lives across the world’s poorest communities.

Inspired by Greg? Why not take on your own challenge by signing up to the Sainsbury’s Sport Relief Games.

Sponsor Greg

attributes.title: British Triathlon cheers Greg James on

attributes.title: You’re helping us win the fight against malaria

body.value:
“I went to bed hoping that I would stay asleep for days or months or years or my entire lifetime. Then I started to harm myself. I thought I might as well do something about not wanting to wake up. One night went really bad. I also stopped eating. These things were becoming addictions. I never liked talk about my emotions. I had to psyche myself up to come to the project but they helped me to make sense of my feelings. I fell down a lot and slipped back, but they kept me going.”

Louise, 17, MYPAS

YPlan, the event discovery and booking platform is today announcing it’s partnered with Sport Relief to raise cash and help people living incredibly tough lives.

The app’s users will now be able to sign up to the Sainsbury’s Sport Relief Games, as well as donate money through YPlan.

The partnership will also give users the ability to buy tickets from a special collection of events with £1 of every ticket going to Sport Relief.

"We are extremely proud to be partnering with such a powerful charitable event this year,” Rytis Vitkauskas, CEO and Co-Founder of YPlan, said.

“Sport Relief brings help to vulnerable people in both the UK and the world’s poorest communities and we are encouraging YPlanners to sign up and support this cause.”

Michele Settle, Director of UK Campaigns and Brands at Comic Relief added: “It’s great to have YPlan on board as a new digital partner for Sport Relief, providing the public with another way to not only sign up to the Sainsbury’s Sport Relief Games but donate through the YPlan collection. It couldn’t be easier to get involved, get active, raise cash and change lives.”

The Sainsbury’s Sport Relief Games take place from March 18 to 20. Sign up now toyour local event to get involved and raise money.
